headline: Best Damn Chili
description: A spicy ground beef chili with an assortment of sweet and hot peppers that's easy to make on your stove or in your slow cooker for a crowd-pleasing meal.

video.description: Perhaps the best chili recipe out there.
video.name: Best Damn Chili

name: Best Damn Chili
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch garlic powder, or to taste
1 (12 fluid ounce) can or bottle light beer (such as Coors®)
1 (28 ounce) can crushed San Marzano tomatoes
2 (16 ounce) cans dark red kidney beans (such as Bush's®)

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat; cook and stir onion, bell pepper, Anaheim pepper, jalapeno peppers, and garlic in the hot oil until softened.
Meanwhile, heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook and stir beef in the hot skillet until browned and crumbly, 5 to 7 minutes.

Add Worcestershire sauce and garlic powder. Crumble bouillon cubes over beef and add beer. Continue to cook , scraping any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet, until liquid is hot, about 3 minutes.
Stir beef mixture into pepper mixture.

Stir crushed tomatoes, diced tomatoes, tomato paste, and wine to the beef mixture. Season with chili powder, 2 tablespoons cumin, brown sugar, pepper sauce, basil, paprika, salt, oregano, and black pepper.
Bring to a boil and reduce heat to medium-low. Cover and simmer until meat and vegetables are very tender and flavors have developed in the chili, about 90 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Mix kidney beans into beef and vegetables. Continue to simmer until beans are hot, about 30 minutes more.
Blend sour cream, cilantro, and remaining 1/2 teaspoon cumin in a food processor until smooth. Serve sour cream mixture with chili.

review.reviewBody: My family loved it!!!!!

Two things, the addition of over powering Kidney beans, But than again I consider Beans a side dish to add later and then only pinto beans. Next Tomato are sweet and high in acid which can cause heartburn. My award winning Recipe has Beef, onions and dried Chilies like Ancho .

I made this recipe for Super Bowl Sunday at the In-Laws place. Everyone enjoyed it, including me. I must confess that in my rush to get all the ingredients, I forgot to buy any of the chiles. Whoops. So, I added more of the chipotle pepper sauce to try to give it the kick that the chilis would have made. It was very mild, but then my wife and her sister loved it that way. Next time I will include the chilis but all in all, it was a hit for our Super Bowl Sunday chili hot dogs. Thanks for such a great recipe! Also, a bit of advice. Get all the ingredients out and ready with the proper measuring devices and things will move along more smoothly. I was rushed and it took me about 2 hours to get it into the crockpot and start simmering while I ran out and played golf in the morning. By 2pm in the afternoon (7 hours later) it was tasting great, just not quite spicy enough without the chilis. I will definitely make it again.
I used ground deer meat! It was absolutely delish!!

This is a good recipe, just not a good chili recipe. The end result tastes more akin to an excellent "sloppy joe" recipe than a chili recipe. Based on reviews, I used 1/2 the amount of tomato paste and could only find a Poblano pepper (not an Anaheim) after trying 2 different stores, so that was my only substitution. If you want to make a great "sloppy joe," this recipe with a bit less liquid would be tremendous. However, if you are seeking a chili recipe, this is not the one to try.
Delicious. Savory but not hot
I made this and it was a hit . I decided to opt out the can of tomato paste thought it was just too much and I think I was right .

The name fits! I used ground moose meat and omitted only the chipotle and chile peppers, because I had neither. Did not do the cremona. Served with sticky rice and some grated cheddar. A hit to be sure! I will make again, and soon!
I loved the complex flavor. I intend to make this again! The only difference was that I used a pablano pepper instead of anaheim.

This has been my go-to chili recipe for 2-3 years now. I make it pretty much exactly as written, except I use green jalapenos rather than red and usually throw an additional yellow bell pepper in the mix. It is great! I typically serve it with sharp cheddar, sliced jalapenos, chopped red onion, sour cream, and cilantro rather than the crema. My husband doesn't particularly like chili, but he gladly eats this when I make it.

Great recipe!! I added hotter peppers and more herbs but our family likes highly seasoned food. FYI, don't leave out the wine it really took the flavor to the next level. I used a cheap white wine from Costco.
Beyond delicious!!

Wow, really best chili ever!!! First time cooking a chili that requires that much simmering. I like my chili soupy and beany; beans were OK, no need of evaporating or thickening liquid. Used half of the beer and completed the 12 Oz with beef broth, and did not used beef bouillon. Followed the sugestion on a review of less tomato paste: used 6 Oz only of basil, garlic, oregano tomato paste. It is medium hot for my taste, only used one large poblano and one large Anaheim peppers. Also followed review suggesting extra bell pepper and onion. Oh yes, with this chili recipe, I will be on the next 'best chili competition' at work!!
Loved it, best chili i have ever made. I used Guinness in place of lighter beer.

The name does not lie. I made it this weekend and it’s so delicious. The flavor is amazing. I was worried it would be spicy but it was perfect. I used Chardonnay and a blue moon for the alcohol. It tasted even better on day 2. The sour cream mixture on top was a game changer. This is definitely going to be my go to chili recipe from now on.
I tried making chili for the first time in my life and I'm really glad I stumbled into this recipe!
Made several times pretty much exactly as noted- made with ground venison and was delicious!!

Amazing recipe! This is great chili. I did make some adjustments though. I used two (1 large, one medium) red conical sweet peppers, one Anaheim pepper, one Poblano pepper, and one green Jalapeño pepper. I did not precisely measure all the spices so there is probably a little more of each in mine than what the recipe called for but not much. I added Cayenne pepper to taste. Instead of two and a half pounds of meat, I used three pounds. I wanted it a little more heartier. Lastly, and my big change which I think made this chili out of this world, I used one pound of Lamb, one pound of Venison, and one pound of Elk. All of which taste so much better than beef and are healthier. Also, I did not make the sour cream mixture. We just used plain old sour cream and shredded sharp cheddar cheese. I added those after I took the picture. My best friend and my girlfriend both commented how much they enjoyed this chili. My best friend also said that it is the best chili that he’s ever had.
It was good. Kidney beans don't go in chili so I substituted Pinto beans

I have used this recipe for 3 years now when I wanted to learn how make chili from scratch. I’m so glad I found this! It is an awesome and flavorful chili that my family LOVES! we like meat more than beans so I add extra meat and less beans. Also love the seasoned sour cream suggested.
Omg! It was the best! And the sour cream blended with cilantro and cumin was fabulous!

Rather than ground meat, I like to get a Boston butt or sirloin tip roast, and chop it up (no food processor, just a real good rough chop) as the protein, and roasted Poblano peppers rather than Anaheim peppers. That creama is something new I’m going to try. Sounds goooood. A pot of rice, Fritos, small elbow noodles, chopped purple onion, and a big pan of cornbread on the side so everyone has their choice for add ins. Making some for us and the neighbors for Halloween. It’s getting to be a big pot of chili time of year.
Very good crowd pleaser! Filling and great for adding toppings to fit personal taste. Will make again!
So flavorful and the best damn chili I've ever ate. I make this every winter.
I agree with others that it has an overwhelming tomato taste. To counteract that and to thin it out just a bit, I added an extra cup of beef broth. It did the trick and was delicious!
I made it per instructions but added one pound of fried bacon using only the fat, Adobo sauce, and expresso. Deep rich flavor, incredible. It's now a heart attack but so good.

I loved the powerful flavor combination on this recipe. My husband found it a little too salty, but I'm still rating it a 5. I would suggest cutting the salt a bit for anyone who is sensitive to salt. I'm not sure if there is such a thing as low-sodium beef boullion, but that might be the solution. I did a mix of finely chopped beef (I had some left over in the freezer) and ground turkey as I didn't have enough of either on hand. I was worried about this mix, but it ended up being delicious. I don't usually take time to rate a recipe, but this one is going to be my go to chili recipe from here on out.
I made it and won my work chili cook off. The cilantro topping made it!

Excellent! Did not find Anaheim chili but used a large Jalapeño pepper. Also used half ground beef and half ground pork. Used slow cooker. Added carrots and mushrooms. Spice profile was perfect. Really good on corn bread.

This is my go-to recipe for chilli. It has been for over a year but I hadn’t reviewed it until now. It really is very flavourful and hearty. I love the kick of spice, and I always make a little guacamole to complete the dish. I halved the recipe since it’s just for two of us, and also read the previous comments about the tomato paste so I only put in a teaspoon.
Excellent.

Definitely needed some more heat. Added 4 dry Arbol and 2 dry California Chile pods; along with 1/2 small can of Chipotle with Adobe Sauce. Now the heat profile initially attacks but quickly levels out and doesn't leave a lasting burn.
I followed the recipe except 1/2 tomato paste to 6oz. Instead of 12oz. It was delicious! Will make again!

This was awful! I think 12 oz of tomato paste was too much…the chili was sour. I followed recipe exact except I did not have the pinch of garlic powder. It looked so good with all of the fresh onions, garlic and peppers.
Excellent recipe! The best I’ve tried an will stick with!

Really enjoyed this one !!! Loved chili as a kid, growing up -- This brought me back home , AND THEN some! The flavor was incredible! I did not use the chipotle pepper sauce because I am not sure what that is, and I also used just a tad less tomato paste, as I thought the recipe called for a bit much. I added a third can of beans ( I did TWO Kidney, and ONE pinto) as I like a more bean-y chili. Other than that, I followed it to the T, and all my guests were raving about it! It was the perfect consistency as well! Throw a bunch of shredded cheese on top, with a side of cornbread, and enjoy! It was worth all the headache trying to find all the ingredients! hahaha.

Great recipe. Didn't have Anaheim or San Marzano tomatoes, or red jalapeño ( COVID). Used three large green jalapeños, basil crushed tomatoes, and only had 4 oz of tomato paste. Used Pinot Noir instead of white wine. Still came out great. Does make a lot.
I did make a few small adjustments per my own tastes (half the cumin, double the brown sugar), and reduced the tomato paste to 6 oz. 100% delicious!
I love this chili! I replace the numerous chilis with pickled jalapenos because they are milder. I also use Michelobe light Cactus Lime that gives it a different flavor.
I love it! I tweek tomatoe paste little. But, I give it an A+

This is a great chili!! My mom doesn’t love spice so I took all the seeds and webs out of the peppers and it was fine for her, but still tasty to me! Also we could not find red jalapeños but the green ones we had seemed perfectly good in it.
Too many steps and not special enough . My version of winging it is as good as this. Fine - not outstanding.

Followed the recipe to the letter and what a waste of $25 worth of ingredients. Way too much tomato paste, half or less will do and the spice notes are completely lost in the overwhelming tomato bath. waste of chili

This chili is super flavorful! I would suggest however, for the spices, start with 1/2 then add to taste. Mine turned out a bit too spicy and I ended up adding 3 cans of stewed tomatoes to tone it down. I didn't however, de-seed the jalapenos which I would do next time.

I’ve won back to back chili contest’s at my job with this recipe. It is delicious and definitely a winner. Some have said the brown sugar shouldn’t go in the chili but that was said by the loser. My family raves about it every time I cook it. Perfect fall and football weather chili.
the name says it all!
I made this with only a pound of beef and 4 oz of tomato paste and it was excellent. I also subbed in a cayenne pepper and Serranos.

We tried this based on the numerous positive comments.

Not impressed at all.

To be honest, it was so bad I wouldn't feed this to people I don't like.
Amazing

Made this as a rookie cooker.
Turned out great.
Highly recommended

I've made this amazing chili recipe several times. Definitely reduce the tomato paste to 4-6 oz., but even if you miss the comments about the tomato paste, as I have once before, it's still great - you may just need to add some extra spice/veggies to balance it out.
Excellent and easy! Love this recipe and will use this from now on. I did add 1/2 cup of cocoa to it to give it a hint of Steak and Shake taste.

I love this recipe! I do make a few alterations that make it even better. I add about half a pound of diced “Conecuh Sausage” which is the best sausage you can find. It adds a wonderful smoky flavor and great juicy texture. Sorry to all y’all northerners. But if you have a Publix near you, that’s where you can find it. It’s an Alabama made sausage, I sincerely recommend it. I agree, 12 oz of tomato paste is too much. I add maybe 4 oz, If you need to thicken your chili up, I suggest making a slurry of 2 tbs cornstarch + 2 TBS of Worcestershire. I also like to use darker beer. This really enhances flavor. I like to use the beef “Better than Bullion” brand instead of cubes. The quality is much better. I also like to mix ancho chili powder, chipotle chili powder with regular chili powder. This creates a nice depth of flavor. And the last touch: USE MEXICAN CREMA SOUR CREAM. It’s authentic and so much better than your your average “Daisy” brand
the title is correct. it is a pretty good chili.

Well what you have to start off with is that it’s not a Texas chili. The chipotle and Anaheim peppers really set it off to another flavor - the brown sugar and cooked chipotle sauce add a sweetness to it. The heat is perfect for me. Not a lingering heat! I did use a ground brisket and pork sausage mix and it came out good. But if you are looking for that Texas red chili this is not it. But if you are looking for a savory chili you gotta try this for something different.

This recipe is fantastic and has a very complex flavor. Lots going on, but not too much of anything. Everything balances out. I added a scant tablespoon of coco powder and it really kicked it off. Gave it a bit of a mole flavor. I think a bit of instant espresso would suit this recipe well too though I didn't try it. I will fit it in somewhere next time. Probably before I add the beer with the bullion. Brilliant recipe on its own though. I've recommended this to friends and family. Thanks!
I only changed with the addition of a tsp. cinnamon and used a pork butt roast along with the other meat. Only chili recipe I will ever adhere to going forward.

Made this and did not follow recipe exactly, but did not change ingredients much. Used homemade beans and shredded chicken (pollo guesado), also used a bit more veggies (fresh tomato, carrot, mushrooms, bitternut squash) along with the peppers. It came out great. Love the Werstershire and beer. Next time I'll add a bay leaf or two. Thanks for a great recipe!

First of all, with some minor tweaks this is indeed the best dang chili I’ve ever had. It won me the chili cook off at church! I have been making this chili for about three years in a row now and it has never let me down. Let me give you guys some advice though: 
1) Don’t add the can of tomato paste. Like at all. Just skip it entirely. The sauce in the cans of tomatoes is more than enough. 
2) Use 2.5lbs of tri tip instead of ground beef. 
3) Use a 16oz can of Sierra Nevada Tropical Torpedo IPA as your beer. If that’s not available, use Sierra Nevada’s Pale Ale.
4) Add way more than 4 cloves of garlic. I use like ten, lol
5) Instead of 2 cans of kidney beans, use one can of kidney beans (DRAINED!) and one can of S&V Pinto Chili Beans (UNDRAINED! That delicious liquid is precious!)
6) Add one teaspoon of molasses at the end as your last step.
... I promise you’ll thank me later

This is the best chili I’ve had. I hate to be one of those people that rave about the recipe then list 1,000 changes so I only made one. I did reduce the amount of Tomato paste to 2 tbl after reading another comment. Recipe is a keeper for sure! Thanks!
Really good recipe! I changed a few things just because of availability but it was still a good road map to make your own recipe. I will make this again. Thank you.

We made a double batch of this and it ended up being one of my most favorite chilis that we have made. We substituted ground red pepper instead of the chipotle pepper sauce and it was very good. Added a little bit of more white wine for a boozy chili. I'd definitely make it again!
The best chili ever! Put in 3 jalapenos. 3.2 pounds of ground beef... only 1 can of beans... slightly heaped spices. Red wine not white. AMAZING. Chipotle especially.
Definitely the best chili recipe! Family loves it, will never make it another way again!

Sorry, but I have to add myself to the growing cadre of negative reviewers. This was the most bland chili recipe I've ever tasted. To me, chili should be rich, savory and a little spicy. This had little flavor beyond the cloying sweetness of the brown sugar and excessive tomato products. Three of us tried it, but the leftovers did not get eaten. These people eat anything, too.

I loved this chili! I didn’t have the Adobe sauce, so I used a can or rotel tomatoes with peppers instead. I doubled the amount of garlic and added 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon, I only used 2 lbs of ground beef, and added 12oz bag of Trader Joe’s frozen roasted corn, a 4oz can of green chilies and just 1 Tablespoon of hot chili powder. I’m so glad to have found this recipe.
My favorite of all time!! I feed all my sons friends who love chili & always have to make a double batch! Thanks for this!!
BEST CHILI EVER! Here’s the changes I made: I omitted the tomato paste and Anaheim chiles. I only used 1.5lbs of ground beef, and I added a can of corn.

Yes. Yes this is the best chili recipe hands down.

I omitted beer for gluten free, added an extra 1/2cup wine. Didnt add cilantro, don't like. One green jalapeño, couldn't find a red one. 

At step three I mixed everything in a Ninja Foodi and set at crock pot low for 8 hours. Delicious. Added sour cream, chives, avocado, and cornbread as sides into it and it was the best chili the whole party ever had.

This is the most insanely delicious chili ever! I live on Maui and used venison my son got with his bow up on the volcano. I also used our local pineapple wine and tropical sunshine girl beer! Basil from my garden, it's the best ever!! Thank you so much for this recipe, can't wait to share it with my family Aloha

I did not have Chipotle pepper sauce, substituted 1/8 tsp dry cayenne pepper seasoning.
This was simple and delicious!! My new go to recipe for Chili!!
Too much cumin and smoke paprika. Will not make it again

I made this yesterday for my chili snob hubby. He absolutely loved it, said, and I quote "this is amazing". The only thing I did change was using a green jalapeno instead of a red. Everything else I followed exactly. This is now in my saved file for definite future use!!!

So good! Was missing a few ingredients used regular jalapeño and did 3, didn’t have garlic powder, used 5-6 garlic cloves, regular diced tomatoes, and added 2 tbl of chipotle purée my family likes spicy. It was excellent, will make again for sure!

Made this tonight pretty much to the recipe called. Boom !! The whole family loved it. Placed over pasta with a side of homemade cornbread. Sour cream and some cheddar. Excellent chili dish. A must try

The BEST chili I've made in years!! I made the following adjustments to tailor it to me and mine: 
- only added 1 jalapeno
- no anaheim pepper
- added 4 chipotle in adobo sauce
- 2 can Rotel Fire Roasted w/ green chilis
- added a can of black beans
- used 1lb ground beef
- 1lb well-marbled steak (small dice)
- 4oz pancetta
For us, it was the perfect amount of spice, salt, texture, flavor. Got 12 good portions out of this recipe and froze 8. Oh, we served with avocado, cilantro, sour cream, shredded cheese and tortilla chips...because the cornbread I made did not turn out lol

I loved everything about making this chili but when I got to the tomato paste I was stymied. An entire 12 oz can? That seemed like waaaay too much with all those tomatoes already in the recipe. As it was my first time making this I thought I should follow the ingredients list exactly. But I shouldn’t have. It was indeed waaay too much tomato paste! This was a lot of work for a chili I had to keep apologizing for. It tasted more like some ground beef in tomato sauce I would advise readers to begin with a tablespoon.
We thought it was way too hot. We used only 1/2 the chili powder. We ended up adding 2 more 28oz cans of diced tomatoes to try to cut it.
This is excellent. My husband doesn’t like spicy so I didn’t add the peppers and my brother who is a butcher and a chef loved it. This is a winner will for sure make again!!!
Cooked the recipe as is and it was delicious!! We finally found our keeper for life chili recipe.

Very good recipe. I actually added some spring black bear meat to the beef and made a double batch (~2 gallons). I stored it and reheated it in a dutch oven while on a camping trip. it was a HUGE hit.
I made this today. Everyone loved it!!! I followed the recipe exactly as listed. It was delicious. I will definitely make it again!

Bland bland and, bland...don't waste your time or money on this recipe. While it has a nice looking and extensive ingredient list, it is definitely not the sum of it's parts. Keep looking at other recipes, maybe something more simple.
The name says it all. Made as written, no substitutions. It is the Best Chili!

I always try to follow a recipe as published. I did the same in this case and the chili was fantastic! Very good depth of flavor, spice level just right, and great consistency. I will try again and play with peppers such as poblano, guajillo and anch, etc. and different meats from ground turkey to sausages.
I like it
Best Chili!
Made this for a work thank you lunch. After assembly, I put it in the crock pot overnight. Not even one drop made it home! It was devoured by 9 hungry women. Thank you for sharing!
This is SO tasty!! I might add another can or two of beans and a little broth when it gets a bit too thick. Otherwise this is a keeper recipe! I will make this many more times!!

Deviated from my normal chili recipe and decided to give this a go... truthfully, I shouldn't have. My wife instantly assumed that is was canned Hormell Chili. In my honest opinion, there was just way to much tomato sauce and paste, additionally it was a bit sweet for our liking. I definitely wouldn't recommend this recipe, nor ill we use it again. I'm sorry for the honesty and I greatly appreciate the try/ attempt.

Let me start by saying my husband detests chili. I make it once a year and freeze it in individual servings for me. After 41 years, I have finally found a recipe he loved. He had 2 servings and asked me to make for to me freeze for the winter. Winner winner chili dinner!!!!!
I never write reviews.... But..... ! This really is the best chili! Made the sour cream as suggested and it was great! Thanks for the recipe!

This is my first food review and I cook a lot. The seasonings were perfect but my grandson is 3 and I eased up a bit on the hot peppers. Everyone thought it was delicious even the grandson. Glad you kept trying for the perfect chili!

This was really good! I made a few substitutions just because of a lack of stuff I had! Instead of white wine I did apple cider vinegar, 2 pounds of turkey burger instead of 2.5 of beef, no Chile sauce, one green jalapeño instead of the 2 red and no aneheim pepper! For the beer I used Bud Light!
Satisfying taste with good Smokey hint. Just right heat for sharing with different people
It’s very good!! Top notch!

Oh, dear, I had high hopes, but this was such a disappointment! I should have read more reviews before making. I agree with another reviewer who said 5-star reviews are misleading when the reviewer has made adjustments. I started with the recipe, and all I could taste was tomato paste and salt (and I left out the 1 tsp salt! 1/4 c. Of Worcestershire sauce is a LOT). I added celery, green pepper, corn, more beans, barley, trying to dilute the tomato paste flavor. Added a lot more sugar to try to balance the acid. Then it was just acidic and sweet. Then went to baking soda, which helped some. Cooked some potatoes with it to try to cut down the salty taste. Ended up employing more experimental means - canned pumpkin, molasses, cocoa powder... in an attempt to salvage it. The end result was a VERY late night and a year’s worth of chili that is just barely edible.

So I am going to start that I followed the exact recipe and cooking directions with a few exceptions, but those exceptions are very minor and they were done to make my version keto friendly. I am giving this recipe five stars because the taste, spices, etc. are SPOT on and make this chili amazing!! I could not modify the recipe to my needs without following this almost to a T.
The only major difference is I did not add the beans (bad for my keto diet) and I listened to other reviews and only added two tablespoons of a 4 oz. can of tomato paste. 
I used a combination of ground/shaved/cubed beef because I could not add beans and I wanted some texture. 
It doesn’t say if the white wine should be dry or sweet so I used some cheap moscato. I made sure to use smoked paprika- there is a difference so pay attention. ;) And was worried because I am not used to a chili smelling smokey. Oh, my heavens! It was soooo good. This is a keeper.

I made this chili last night and it was delicious!! I've made many different chili recipes over the years, but this one is a keeper! I will continue to make it! I did make some modifications as to my own preferences such as used shredded chicken instead of beef and chicken broth rather than beef bouillon, and added a pinch of cinnamon and added some dollops of Cilantro creme sauce over the top as another user suggested as well as a little apple cider vinegar, but I adhered to the rest of the recipe and it was excellent. A lot of depth and a good amount of spice that blended in well together with the tomato base. So yummy - will proudly be serving this at family events to come paired with cornbread muffins!
